p: In Mengla County of China, there is also a plant named ‘fleagrass’, Adenosma buchneroides. Similar to the Polygonum in Estonia, fleagrass is an insect-repellent plant that is used by the Akha people. However, fleagrass plays a broader and more important role in the culture of Akha. Akha people wear it on the head every day, because they like the smell and regard it as the symbol of Akha [ 12]. The smell is also good for relaxing and comforting the body. In traditional Akha medicine, the whole plant has medicinal value in anti-rheumatic, diminishing swelling, dissipate stasis, and analgesia [ 13]. The essential oil of fleagrass exhibited a good reduction of the population of adult insects [ 14]. Chemical constituents of the essential oil of fleagrass have been identified, with 39 chemical compounds reported. The main constituents include thymol, carvacrol, 3-carene, p-cymene, and β-phellandrene [ 12, 15]. These chemicals show antimicrobial, antioxidant, phytotoxic, and insecticidal activities [ 16– 19].
